content.webTitle: Morning Mail: Gough Whitlam dies aged 98, burqa ban backdown, almost 600k metadata requests

fields.headline: Morning Mail: Gough Whitlam dies aged 98, burqa ban backdown, almost 600k metadata requests
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday. Gough Whitlam dies aged 98 In breaking news this morning, former prime minister Gough Whitlam has died at the age of 98. We have Whitlam’s life in pictures, and from the archives,the Guardian’s coverage of his 1975 dismissal. More coverage coming at theguardian.com/au Burqa ban backdown Early yesterday, Bronwyn Bishop backed down on the “burqa ban” in parliament. It emerged that Bishop and Stephen Parry personally added the controversial “burqa ban” to official security advice without consulting Asio or the AFP. Later it was revealed the ban on facial covering was imposed because of an anonymous radio rumour about a protest that never actually happened. The rumour was passed on from the AFP, who heard it from a 9 News crew, who themselves heard the rumour on 2UE. After a terrorist threat overreaction that caused so much damage, parliament has been left with a headache as questions are asked over how the “burqa ban” came about in the first place, writes political editor Lenore Taylor. It was such a strange day in Canberra, deputy political editor Katharine Murphy could only describe it as “a slow slide into crazy town”. Read back on the events of a “compelling day for all the wrong reasons”. And follow all the events from Canberra today as our politics live blog kicks off again. Australian news and politics • Almost 600,000 separate government requests were made for Australians’ phone, location and web data last year, far higher than the 300,000 requests disclosed by the attorney general’s department. A department spokesman said: “There is no conflict between the AGD [attorney general’s department] and ACMA reports.” • Report predicts bushfire season ‘will be more severe as result of climate change’, and the economic cost of fires will triple by 2050 and urges reduction in carbon emissions. • The only program in the southern hemisphere actively searching for potentially hazardous comets, asteroids and meteors - the one that discovered the Siding Spring comet just last year - was shut down after losing funding. “It’s a real worry. There could be something hurtling towards us right now and we wouldn’t know about it.” Around the world • Turkey to allow Kurdish peshmerga across its territory to fight in Kobani, marking a dramatic shift in the Turkish position that could tip a month-long battle against Isis insurgents. • Before and after aerial pictures show the extent of destruction from weeks of fighting between Islamic State and Kurdish forces in Kobani • The theme for annual conference of China’s Communist party will be ‘rule of law’ but only small local reforms expected from party that operates above the constitution. • Nepal ends blizzard mountain search, as officials say all hikers believed to have been stranded are now rescued after the snowstorms that left dozens dead. More from around the web • Among the most read on the Guardian this morning: Transport chiefs are investigating after a gay couple were told they were “disgusting” and then ‘thrown off’ a bus after the driver saw them sharing a kiss. • The AFP are poised to seize assets of corrupt Chinese officials within weeks, in an unprecedented joint operation with their Chinese counterparts, the Sydney Morning Herald reports. • Three out of five Australians are in favour of Tony Abbott confronting Vladimir Putin over the shooting down of MH17 when he visits Australia for the G20 next month, according to the latest Newspoll, The Australian reports. • Officers of ASIS have fired guns while affected by alcohol, and then the intelligence agency lied to IGIS about it, the annual report of the intelligence oversight body reveals, Crikey reports. One last thing Researchers at ANU have created a laser tractor beam. One of the researchers says this is pretty much the “holy grail for laser physicists”, a long-distance optical tractor beam that can repel and attract objects. Have an excellent day – and if you spot anything I’ve missed, let me know in the comments here or on Twitter @earleyedition.
